comment.author: 70176701@N02
comment._content: It appears there was a huge amount of concern as to whether he was indeed killed on the day mentioned or taken prisioner by the Germans. A lot of letters were written by his sister trying to find out what had happened to him. His wife was started on a widows pension and then later told to keep drawing his pay as no one knew if he was really dead or not. I believe Arthur came from a town called Port Pirie in Australia. His discription was - hieght 4ft 6, thick set, dark complexion, dark hair starting to go grey and grey eyes. Information from www.awm.gov.au

comment._content: From www.cwgc.org.uk Rank:Private Service No:2238 Date of Death:05/11/1916 Age:30 Regiment/Service:Australian Infantry, A.I.F. 27th Bn. Panel Reference MemorialVILLERS-BRETONNEUX MEMORIAL Additional Information:Son of John Samuel and Mary Ann Thorn; husband of K. M. Thorn, of Port Pirie, South Australia. Born at Paratoo, South Australia. THORN.-In sacred and loving memory of our dear Arthur (Signaller 27th Battalion), officially posted as killed in action at Flers on November 5, 1916; and of his brother, Signaller R. S. Thom, who made the supreme sacrifice at Pozieres on July 24, 1916. They are not dead they have but passed, Beyond the mists that blind us here, Into the new and larger life Of that serener sphere; And ever near us, though unseen, The dear immortal spirits tread. For all the boundless universe In life: there are no dead. "He that liveth and believe in Me shall never die." Inserted by their loving parents (M. A. and J. S. Thorn) and sisters and brothers. FOR KING AND COUNTRY. trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/45568275 A tree on www.ancesty.co.uk shows his parents as John Samuel Thorn and Mary Ann Bishop. His wife was Kathleen M Bond. Australia Birth Index shows his birth in 1886 Cavenagh, South Australia.
